blurb: For the past six months, PolitiFact has been cataloging promises Trump made to voters in speeches, appearances, interviews and debates. Tuesday we launch our Trump-O-Meter, which will track 102 of the most significant pledges emblematic of his unconventional campaign. The Trump-O-Meter will measure whether Trump is able to accomplish what he told voters and ultimately rate each promise Kept, Broken or Compromise. It’s the same process we used to track the campaign promises made by President Barack Obama.

blurb:
Americans for Prosperity, the conservative group funded by the Koch brothers, is going after the Democratic candidate in Michigan's open U.S. Senate race for voting for the Affordable Care Act.

In a 60-second ad, Julie Boonstra, a Michigan woman with leukemia, explains how she lost her insurance because it did not meet standards for coverage set by Obamacare. She claims by voting for President Barack Obama's health law, Rep. Gary Peters, D-Mich., put her life at risk and stuck her with a policy that was unaffordable.

While a harrowing account, there's a lot more to this story than the ad lets on.

blurb:
If you've followed the campaign, you've heard a version of it: To pay for Obamacare, President Barack Obama would harm seniors by cutting $716 billion from Medicare.

blurb:
Watching debates is now a two-screen affair.

Many people have their smartphone, tablet or laptop with them so they can look things up as the candidates trade talking points. Make PolitiFact one of your resources.

We’ll be live fact-checking all the presidential debates this month and have some special coverage planned. Here are some tips on how to use PolitiFact as you watch them:

* Use our free app, Settle It! PolitiFact's Argument Ender. Available for iPhone and Android, Settle It! has an easy-to-use search feature that allows you to enter names and keywords and find the Truth-O-Meter articles that answer your question. (Although we don't have a separate iPad version, the iPhone app works great on the iPad.)

Keep reading...

blurb:
Georgetown University law student Sandra Fluke told an unofficial hearing of the Democratic Steering and Policy Committee on Feb. 23, 2012, that the omission of contraceptive coverage by her Jesuit school created "financial, emotional and medical burdens" for students.

Her comments caught the ear of conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh, who called Fluke a slut and a prostitute demanding that taxpayers pay for her to have sex. You've probably heard Limbaugh's words (for which he later said he apologized) repeated plenty. Here's what Fluke said that ignited his ire.

blurb:
The Republican debate in Tampa turned into a sparring match Monday night as Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney attacked each other on their records in political office.

Gingrich began the debate with a spirited defense of his record as speaker of the House of Representatives. He repeated a claim we've heard before, that "When I was speaker, we had four consecutive balanced budgets." In fact, two of those balanced budgets occured after he left office. We rated that claim False.

Romney attacked Gingrich for his record, claiming that "at the end of four years, he had to resign in disgrace. We interviewed experts about Gingrich's resignation and found that it was more complicated than Romney described.

blurb: Mitt Romney says he helped create 100,000 new jobs. Critics say he's been a job destroyer. But who's right? Fact-checkers and other journalists have repeatedly looked at the history of Bain Capital, the investment firm Romney ran from 1984 to 1999. Bottom line? It's tough to prove job claims on either side — not that we won't try.

blurb:
President Barack Obama has declared himself a Christian. He has worshipped in Christian churches, prayed with Christian ministers, and recounted how he knelt beneath a cross and felt God's spirit.

And yet, a surprising number of Americans keep telling pollsters they believe he's a Muslim.

The Pew Research Center last week reported that 18 percent of Americans believe Obama is a Muslim, up from 11 percent in March 2009. A Time magazine poll also released last week found even more -- 24 percent -- said he was a Muslim.

blurb: "Clinton pastor" convicted of child sex abuse, says a newspaper Web site and a posting on an Obama campaign blog. It's a recipe for outrage.
headline: It's not the Clinton you think

blurb: The senator's birth overseas in a military zone raises a vexing question about whether he's eligible to be president. Since the issue rests on legal opinions, we'll explain the arguments but skip the Truth-O-Meter.
headline: Was McCain born in the USA?

blurb: John McCain says Hamas has endorsed Barack Obama. We find it's not an official endorsement, but it's certainly effusive praise.
headline: A terrorist endorsement for Obama?

blurb: Sen. John McCain's new health care plan brings the issue back in focus for the presidential candidates. We check three new claims.
headline: Candidates get back to health

blurb: We've made a few improvements to PolitiFact. For the first time, we're providing a tally of our ratings for each candidate and group.
headline: By request: keeping count

blurb: The gas tax won't save you much and supercars will have to wait. Why can't there be an easy answer for sticker shock at the pump?
headline: Polled position: gas taxes and supercars

blurb: The latest scurrilous e-mail about Barack Obama has real-live authors, Christian missionaries in Africa, but they're no better with the truth than anonymous bloggers.
headline: Even missionaries botch their facts

blurb: Clinton — and Obama — spoke up early on mortgage problems.
headline: Clinton's long haul on foreclosures

blurb: McCain chastises the North Carolina GOP for political ads that use the Rev. Jeremiah Wright; then McCain weighs in other Wright statements.
headline: McCain steps in on Wright

blurb: McCain gets it half right on capital gains taxes while debate moderators pin down Clinton and Obama on where they stand.
headline: Capital gains taxes demystified

blurb: Voting records make senators east targets for attack ads, and nobody knows it better than Sen. John McCain. The DNC is only doing what George W. Bush did back in 2000.
headline: A lesson in cherry-picking

blurb: The Rev. Wright was one of more than 100 religious leaders invited to a prayer breakfast at the White House in 1998, but there's no indication he provided the Clintons any spiritual counseling.
headline: Wright not Clinton's spiritual adviser

blurb: The RNC is right that Obama once supported a gas tax "holiday," but a video glosses over some key details.
headline: Gas taxes, on holiday

blurb: An e-mail by Focus on the Family uses some inaccurate information to paint a misleading portrait of Barack Obama.
headline: Focus on the facts

blurb: As the Pennsylvania primary looms, health care takes center stage in campaign ads
headline: In Pa., 11th-hour attacks on health care

blurb: Small pin ignites larger controversies
headline: Flag pin flap tarnishes Obama, journos

blurb: Dueling ads from Obama and Clinton say their opponent is weak on Big Oil. We find some truth and exaggerations on both sides.
headline: Trying to be tough on Big Oil

blurb: The Philly debate was a relatively tame affair, but it brought a new controversy into the campaign: Obama's ties to a former member of the Weather Underground. We check the facts.
headline: Vanilla in Phila.

blurb: John McCain says energy prices would go down if the U.S. stopped filling the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. They might, but not by much.
headline: McCain energy claim low on fuel

blurb: If a candidate is off with a statistical claim, should they earn a False on the Truth-O-Meter?
headline: Numbers game

blurb: Small donors are a civic good, but they're not the whole picture when it comes to public campaign finance.
headline: 'Parallel public financing'? Only partly.

blurb: Obama claims he was the driving force on ethics reform. We find he was a player but not the quarterback.
headline: Obama's stretch on ethics reform

blurb: In defending his wife's mistakes about sniper fire in Bosnia, Bill Clinton makes a few of his own.
headline: Bill's Bosnia blunder

blurb: MoveOn e-mails out a 10-point attack on McCain. On domestic policy, its aim is good.
headline: In the e-mail: MoveOn flames McCain

blurb: The latest chain e-mail attack on Obama distorts the words in the Bible to suggest he is the Antichrist.
headline: Obama is the Antichrist? Puh-leeze!

blurb: We find Obama is right about how much households pay for the war.
headline: The Iraq war, for $100 month

blurb: A chain e-mail uses apples-to-oranges comparisons to assert that Obama is a more active senator than Clinton.
headline: Manipulating the bill counts

blurb: We compare the legislative accomplishments of the Democratic candidates.
headline: FACT SHEET: Clinton. Obama. Their bills.

blurb: Former President Bill Clinton claims Sen. Barack Obama "said one thing and did another" by accepting lobbyist money.
headline: President Clinton again on attack

blurb: In an exclusive interview with PolitiFact, the former Alaska senator confirms his status in the presidential campaign.
headline: Gravel: I'm not dead yet

blurb: It's all over the news that Sen. Barack Obama claims Sen. John McCain will let the war in Iraq go on for 100 years. Obama is taking liberties with what McCain said, as we told you weeks ago.
headline: 100 years of latitude

blurb: Video footage shows meet-and-greet but no snipers on First Lady's 1996 Bosnia trip
headline: Trip details trip Clinton

blurb: A chain e-mail on taxes makes a lot of points, not all of them right.
headline: Chain e-mail fudges tax numbers

blurb: Sen. John McCain makes two gaffes during a trip overseas, but thankfully, good pal Sen. Joe Lieberman is there to bail him out.
headline: It's Lieberman to the rescue

blurb: An ad says McCain mimics Bush on Iraq, taxes, oil and health care. We say not on oil.
headline: 'McSame' ad goes three for four

blurb: In his AIPAC speech, Obama said chain e-mails have been distorting his position on Israel. In this article, we examine some of the charges and whether there is any truth to them.
headline: Obama and Israel

blurb: The Pennsylvania primary is six weeks away, but the charges have been flying fast and furiously. We check the facts on some claims.
headline: Keystone attacks

blurb: Clinton says she's skilled at foreign affairs because of her work as first lady on Northern Ireland, China and Kosovo. We check the facts to see what she did.
headline: Ready for the 3 a.m. call?

blurb: We examine Barack Obama's resume and find 20 years of public service work.
headline: Obama's 20 years of experience

blurb: Sen. John McCain and Sen. Barack Obama are engaged in a battle on the validity of a March 2007 agreement to accept public financing — and its $84.1-million limit — for the general election.
headline: Campaign finance: Deal or no deal?

blurb: In November, the Republican National Committee oversimplified the cost of Sen. Hillary Clinton's policy proposals. Now, the RNC does a similarly overstated assessment of Sen. Barack Obama's plans.
headline: Spend-O-Meter vs. Truth-O-Meter, Part II

blurb: In the Cleveland showdown between the Democrats, Obama and Clinton get fast and loose with the facts. We find Clinton is right about Obama's committee work but is wrong that he wants to bomb Pakistan.
headline: Mistakes on the lake

blurb: Sen. Hillary Clinton has promoted her plan to address the foreclosure crisis with various freezes, but she sometimes leaves crucial details out of her public comments. Sen. Barack Obama, meanwhile, takes aim at the inflated rhetoric and misses.
headline: Unpacking the home mortgage plans

blurb: Barack Obama charges Hillary Clinton with flip-flopping on NAFTA. He repeats a false detail, while getting the big picture right.
headline: Obama bashes Clinton on NAFTA

blurb: PolitiFact has been named the "Best Overall Newspaper Web Site" in the Newspaper Association of America Digital Edge awards.
headline: PolitiFact named top news site

blurb: The top Democrats offer competing visions of leadership, but their voting records are nearly identical.
headline: FACT SHEET: Clinton. Obama. Votes.

blurb: The Democratic debate in Austin was a polite affair. But we found plenty of facts to check.
headline: Texas Two-Step

blurb: The senator who sang "bomb Iran" claims that Barack Obama wants to bomb Pakistan. We find McCain is distorting Obama's remarks and give the Arizona Republican our Pants On Fire rating.
headline: McCain sings off tune

blurb: The New York senator often boasts of 35 years in politics. We do the math and find one of her claims is way off, but that her general point about political experience is largely accurate.
headline: Adding up Clinton's 35-year claim

blurb: A chain e-mail says Clinton sympathized with the Black Panthers and interned for a law firm run by a Communist. The source? An article by Clinton adviser-turned-foe Dick Morris.
headline: Clinton's not-so-radical past

blurb: Attacks by conservatives became so sharp last week that Sen. John McCain asked for a cease-fire. Here's a look at why they're unhappy and what PolitiFact has said about their complaints.
headline: 5 conservative concerns about McCain

blurb: When he was in the Illinois state senate, Barack Obama sometimes voted to block bills without formally opposing them, which has raised questions of political expedience.
headline: Obama's "present" tension

blurb: Bill Clinton inaccurately defends his own statements from the campaign trail, while George W. Bush takes a questionable shot at Barack Obama.
headline: When presidents play politics

blurb: In a Virginia speech, Barack Obama said polls show he could beat John McCain by 6 points. We find he's right about the polls, but wrong about gas prices and he misstates what Hillary Clinton's said about a bankruptcy bill.
headline: Hope . . . and the facts

blurb: Clinton has the endorsement of Jack Nicholson. McCain has Sylvester Stallone. Ron Paul is backed by a late-night radio personality named Waldo. We examine the endorsements of each candidate.
headline: FACT SHEET: Endorsements

blurb: Obama's "present" votes on abortion in the Illinois senate become fodder for Clinton attacks.
headline: The Obama abortion debate

blurb: In the final hours before Super Tuesday, the candidates traded charges on everything from the economy to political pork. We examined their claims and found they were largely correct.
headline: Super scramble

blurb: At the heart of a speech promoting his own candidacy, Obama charges that Clinton and McCain are too much alike at a time when Democrats need to present a clear distinction.
headline: Obama: Clinton too much like McCain

blurb: We check the facts from the Republican debate and again find John McCain is incorrect when he says Mitt Romney supported a timetable to withdraw from Iraq.
headline: Showdown in Simi Valley

blurb: We check out the latest on President Bush's economic stimulus package and where the candidates stand on economic issues.
headline: FACT SHEET: Economic policy

blurb: The ever quotable Rudy Giuliani gave PolitiFact lots of things to check this election season. Here's a look back at highlights from the Giuliani file. We mark John Edwards' departure as well.
headline: So long, Mayor Giuliani

blurb: John McCain makes fun of Mitt Romney for changing positions on abortion and gun control. McCain's jibes may not be polite, but they are accurate.
headline: Another flap over flip-flops

blurb: In an attack shortly before voters headed to the polls in Florida, John McCain brings up Iraq, saying Mitt Romney urges a withdrawal date. But we find Romney won't set a timetable for leaving.
headline: McCain's last-minute attack about Iraq

blurb: We find some exaggerations and mistakes at the Republican debate in Boca Raton.
headline: Fumbled facts in Florida

blurb: Mike Huckabee says a national Fair Tax will be like a "magic wand." We say magic wands don't exist.
headline: Adding up the Fair Tax

blurb: The Democratic debate in Myrtle Beach featured sharp comments by Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton. We found Clinton continued to distort Obama's comments about Ronald Reagan, while other claims were closer to the truth.
headline: He said, she said

blurb: Hillary Clinton says the Pentagon is trying to take away the signing bonuses of soldiers who get wounded in combat and that she's part of an effort in Congress to end the practice. But her words are somewhat misleading.
headline: The military signing bonus squabble

blurb: In a TV ad aimed at voters in Florida, Rudy Giuliani makes claims about cutting taxes, welfare reform and a national insurance fund. We find he's mostly right on two, but wrong on the other.
headline: Rudy's Florida pitch

blurb: In a flashback to 2000, Sen. John McCain faces unfounded allegations about his past. This time, a flyer from the Vietnam Veterans Against John McCain alleges he's a traitor.
headline: McCain's POW record attacked, again

blurb: The Democratic candidates held a friendly chit-chat in Las Vegas. We found they got some facts right and stretched the truth with a few others.
headline: Pulling punches in Vegas

blurb: Heading into the South Carolina primaries this month, immigration is a hot topic in the Republican race. Specifically, Sen. John McCain's role and the issue of "amnesty."
headline: The fight over 'amnesty'

blurb: A breakdown of the immigration issue, including candidate-by-candidate positions.
headline: FACT SHEET: Immigration

blurb: A Clinton attack on Barack Obama's Iraq record turns into a campaign brawl. We look at what's a fairy tale and what's not.
headline: The "Fairy Tale" Fracas

blurb: An anonymous e-mail says Barack Obama belongs to a racist, anti-American church. We find that the church teaches black empowerment, not racism, and that it claims Africa as its ethnic heritage. We also find, yet again, that Obama isn't Muslim.
headline: E-mail slams Obama on religion, race

blurb: St. Petersburg Times Editor Paul Tash is a moderator at the Jan. 24 GOP presidential debate in Boca Raton, and he wants to make sure your concerns are addressed. If you have a question in mind for the candidates, time to step up to the mike! Click here to send your question.
headline: Send a debate question

blurb: Rudy Giuliani makes a case that the United States lags behind foreign nations when it comes to energy infrastructure. But he overstates the foreign energy juggernaut and ignores enormous energy investments at home.
headline: Giuliani's energy juggernaut

blurb: A building in the Cayman Islands houses thousands of corporations. Sen. Barack Obama calls it "the biggest tax scam on record." But until legislation currently proposed by Obama and others becomes law, it isn't.
headline: Obama targets Cayman 'tax scam'

blurb: Hundreds of readers have signed up for our twice-weekly e-mail, which describes our latest rulings. To sign up, click here.
headline: Truth-O-Mail

blurb: Our story about the Obama chain e-mail was suggested by a PolitiFact reader. If you have a suggestion for facts or chain e-mails we should check, click here to email us.
headline: What should we check?

blurb: Wondering what Obama has accomplished in the Senate? Here's our examination of the candidates' Senate accomplishments, which was prompted by a New Year's Eve attack by Sen. Joe Biden.
headline: Examining their Senate records

blurb: It's a matter of opinion which Democratic front-runner is the candidate of change, but here are some PolitiFact rulings that might help you decide.
headline: Who's the candidate of change?

blurb: A strident letter attacks Romney's religion and argues -- falsely -- that Mormons want to rescind the U.S. Constitution.
headline: Anti-Mormon screed targets Romney

blurb: We find some truth, some exaggerations and a Pants-on-Fire falsehood at the dual debates in New Hampshire.
headline: Two parties, one night

blurb: We're checking facts from the dual debates in New Hampshire. We've got our first item posted on the left, about Rudy Giuliani's misleading claim on defense. We'll have others posted as we get them checked.
headline: Dual debates

blurb: Romney says McCain has flip-flopped on the Bush tax cuts. He's right, but McCain has an explanation.
headline: Romney's tax claim against McCain

blurb: The campaign has its first attack dog - and he's right! Check out our fact-check of Spike's attack in the lower left of this page.
headline: Mitt's mutt mauls Mike

blurb: PolitiFact bids farewell to Joe Biden, the only two-time winner of our coveted "Pants on Fire!" rating.
headline: Goodbye, Joe

blurb: Amid much fanfare, Mike Huckabee last week announced he was refusing to air a negative ad attacking Mitt Romney. But our friends at FactCheck.org have discovered the ad has aired at least 10 times.
headline: Huckabee ad aired

blurb: No one doubts Mike Huckabee's sincerity as a social conservative, but his sympathy tax hikes and government programs haunts him.
headline: Huckabee's 'liberal' problem

blurb: With just three days until the Iowa caucuses, the candidates are unleashing a flurry of charges -- and making a few slip-ups.
headline: Fast and furious finish

blurb: The two former governors have been criticizing each other about pardons. We find their claims are accurate and reveal starkly different approaches on clemency.
headline: Pardon me: Huckabee vs. Romney

blurb: The former Arkansas governor says he had the "most impressive" education record among the GOP pack. But open-ended superlatives are tough to prove, especially when you've got critics.
headline: He didn't stand in the way, but he didn't always lead

blurb: The PolitiFact staff will be taking a few days off so we can fact-check the caloric content of Christmas cookies (especially the ones with icing and those little sprinkles). We'll be back with new items on Wednesday.
headline: Ho ho ho!

blurb: They want to be commander in chief, but most of the presidential candidates have not served in the military. Our survey of their resumes finds that five of the 15 candidates have military experience.
headline: FACT SHEET: Who was in military?

blurb: If you're chilly today, scroll down to the lower left of our home page and warm your hands by our Attack File. It is ablaze with three Pants on Fire rulings for chain e-mails.
headline: Warm your hands

blurb: An anonymous e-mail claims Barack Obama is a Muslim, attended a madrassa as a boy and took the oath of office on a Koran. The Truth-O-Meter says wrong, wrong and wrong.
headline: Obama used a Koran? No, he didn't

blurb: Mitt Romney says he's following the same path as Ronald Reagan, Henry Hyde and George H.W. Bush when it comes to changing positions on abortion, but his turn was sharper than theirs.
headline: Romney loves company, but they don't quite belong together

blurb: Presidential candidates often make historical references to emphasize points or justify positions. A lot of the time, though, they get their facts wrong -- to the dismay of historians.
headline: History is not their best subject

blurb: Our Top 10 Truth-O-Meter rulings cover the Pledge of Allegiance, military shrinkage and crime linkage. We also examine whether God has a position on the Iowa caucuses.
headline: PolitiFact's greatest hits

blurb: Democrats want you to know the income gap between the rich and the rest of us is at highs not seen since the eve of the Great Depression. That doesn't mean it's Bush's fault.
headline: Income gap is big, but so are its causes

blurb: In the final Republican debate, Rudy Giuliani used some creative new math to exaggerate his record on adoptions, while Fred Thompson was on target about taxes.
headline: Iowa nice

blurb: An anonymous e-mail makes the case that Sen. Clinton holds the same beliefs as Karl Marx and Joseph Stalin by using communist-sounding quotes. But the e-mail presents her statements out of context or distorts them.
headline: Commie e-mail quiz gets an F

blurb: Despite the icy weather in Iowa, the candidates are debating in Des Moines. Check back later for coverage of the Wednesday's Republican debate and Thursday's Democratic debate.
headline: Icy debates

blurb: Mitt Romney's record as governor of Massachusetts and as a candidate for office put him in a vulnerable position as rival Republicans attack his past.
headline: Romney haunted by liberal past

blurb: Hillary Clinton is right about the tangled rules of federal food inspections. If you think the sandwich rules are silly, check out the guidelines for pepperoni pizza.
headline: Ham & cheese, hold the bureaucracy

blurb: Put a little PolitiFact on your Web site. We now have a free widget that will put our latest Truth-O-Meter rulings on your site. You can find it here.
headline: Get the widget

blurb: The former Massachusetts governor bashes so-called HillaryCare while others accuse him of using it.
headline: Romney's Hillary health care problem

blurb: The Clinton campaign trots out quotes from Obama's kindergarten teacher to prove that he's been aiming for the White House longer than he admits. Seriously.
headline: Ridiculous, petty —  but true

blurb: We've opened a store on CafePress.com for Truth-O-Meter T-shirts that say "I believe Mike Gravel," "I don't believe Mike Gravel," etc. for each candidate. You can order "True" shirts for your favorite and "Pants on Fire" shirts for your foes. Click here to check them out.
headline: "I believe Mike Gravel"

blurb: Romney's hard charge on immigration glosses over details of a complex issue.
headline: Romney's In-State Tuition Charge

blurb: Rudy Giuliani joined the Iraq Study Group but then never made it to a meeting.
headline: Giuliani left Iraq panel - or it left him

blurb: Clinton says Obama leaves 15-million uncovered; he calls his plan "universal." Who's right?
headline: Clinton vs. Obama: dueling health plans

blurb: We surveyed the 16 candidates to find out which ones have visited Iraq since the start of the war in March 2003. As of December 2007, nine have. Here are our findings along with a brief synopsis of each candidate's position on the war, taken from their Web sites.
headline: FACT SHEET: Who has been to Iraq?

blurb:
Check out Emily Yahr's analysis of PolitiFact in the new issue of the American Journalism Review. Also, take a look at Clark Hoyt's column Fact and Fiction on the Campaign Trail in Sunday's New York Times, which urges the paper to come up with something similar to our Truth-O- Meter. He says the NYT, "with its own rich Web offerings on the presidential campaign, would do well to showcase a similar fact-checking feature. Maybe the YouTube community could come up with the title, the music video and a truthfulness scale."

[Hey NYT editors! Save your money and just put our Truth-O-Meter widget on your page!]
headline: 'Policing the pols'

blurb: In an essay, PolitiFact editor Bill Adair explains why facts are important — and why we nitpick.
headline: Why facts matter

blurb: At the CNN/YouTube debate, the candidates argued about immigration, crime and Iraq. We found they generally got their facts right, although Huckabee distorted the facts on an education program for immigrants and Romney missed an easy one about the Red Sox.
headline: Romney misses easy grounder

blurb: The Truth-O-Meter will be busy tonight. Check back late tonight or early tomorrow for our full coverage of the CNN/YouTube debate in St. Petersburg.
headline: Fact-checking tonight's debate

blurb: Each of the candidates running for the Republican nomination for president claims to be a conservative. And each one is -- to a point.
headline: Looking for Mr. Right

blurb: Romney and Giuliani cite different statistics on Massachusetts crime to make their points.
headline: Giuliani and Romney duel on crime stats

blurb: PolitiFact will be taking a break for Thanksgiving, so we can fact-check whether the L-tryptophan in turkey really makes you sleepy. (We think some naps will help our research.) We'll be back with new items on Monday. Happy Thanksgiving!
headline: Gobble, gobble!

blurb: Rudy Giuliani presided over an economic rebound in New York City, but his claims ignore the nation's economic expansion. And he doesn't mention the less rosy details of his tenure.
headline: Who made Big Apple sweeter?

blurb: Clinton and Richardson are right that Americans are frustrated with long college aid forms, but their numbers don't add up.
headline: Frustration with forms

blurb: Once you accept some assumptions about how they did the math, the RNC does a pretty good job crunching Clinton's numbers.
headline: Spend-O-Meter vs. Truth-O-Meter

blurb: Rudy Giuliani blames President Clinton for the sad state of the intelligence budget.
headline: The intel numbers game

blurb: Barack Obama says John Edwards is new to populism, but a review of Edwards' political resume shows he has long argued the cause of regular people against economic elites.
headline: Edwards not new to populism

blurb: Rudy Giuliani and Mitt Romney tussled over "sanctuary cities" for illegal immigrants at the CNN/YouTube debate. But their attacks exaggerate the effects of municipal policies on immigration.
headline: No sanctuary from exaggeration

blurb: The Democrats slugged it out in a Las Vegas debate. We found several claims were true, but Obama was wrong about the probability of lightning strikes vs. undocumented worker prosecutions and Richardson was way off about the popularity of Vice President Cheney and HMOs.
headline: Obama zapped by lightning claim

blurb: Fred Thompson says Mike Huckabee raised lots of taxes in Arkansas. Huckabee responds that he cut taxes "almost 100 times." We find Thompson on solid ground but Huckabee stretching the truth.
headline: Taking stock of 'tax-hike Mike'

blurb: Rudy Giuliani frequently attacks Hillary Clinton over her views on the free market, but he's blatantly misquoting her.
headline: Making 'disruption' equal 'destruction'

blurb: Sen. Clinton's records as first lady are stuck in an archivist quagmire, but that doesn't mean President Clinton couldn't be helping.
headline: Decoding the Clinton records ruckus

blurb: A chain e-mail says Barack Obama is unpatriotic because he "refused" to say the Pledge of Allegiance and did not put his hand over his heart. But it relies on a photo taken during the national anthem, not the pledge.
headline: Obama targeted in chain e-mail

blurb: It's true that Rudy Giuliani sued to end the president's line item veto, it's just not clear how much that means.
headline: Sparring over spending

blurb: To see a chart comparing the government and private-sector experience of the candidates, click here.
headline: Compare their resumes

blurb: The candidates have been making boasts and attacking each other over who has the most experience. We check their math.
headline: What's in a resume?

blurb: The barbers in the TV ads aren't real, but they're correct that Dodd was the prime sponsor of the Family and Medical Leave Act.
headline: Barbers give Dodd a good cut

blurb: The Delaware senator says he's the one who lowered crime in New York while Rudy Giuliani was mayor.
headline: Biden wants a bite of the Big Apple

blurb: Candidates pillory the alternative minimum tax, though not always with solutions in hand.
headline: Not just for the richest anymore

blurb: Surviving his own cancer scare doesn't protect Giuliani from drawing fire over disputed statistics.
headline: A cancer ad gone wrong for Rudy

blurb: Coming soon: a twice-weekly e-mail highlighting our newest Truth-O-Meter items! Get the truth in your inbox! Watch this space for the sign-up in the next few days!
headline: Coming soon: Truth-O-Mail!

blurb: Mitt Romney backs the Bush administration's key education accountability reforms, saying that high-stakes testing has worked wonders for his state.
headline: Why Romney likes No Child Left Behind

blurb: Obama and Clinton argue about Iran, but they agree on most aspects of U.S. policy.
headline: The "blank check" brouhaha

blurb: As the attacks increase, we're checking lots of claims and adding new items to our Attack File. You'll find them in the lower left of this page.
headline: Attack-o-rama

blurb: Bill Richardson and other critics overstate the drawbacks of John Edwards' decision to take public financing
headline: The perils of public financing

blurb: Update: Fred Thompson has a mixed record on tort reform. He's opposed some bills because of his preference for states' rights, but supported others.
headline: Thompson torn on torts

blurb: A gay Republican group attacks Romney with his own record.
headline: Sly ad attacks Romney

blurb: To illustrate his concerns about a fence between the United States and Mexico, Bill Richardson cites problems with the Great Wall of China and the Berlin Wall. But the history of those famous fences is not so clear.
headline: A divide over fences

blurb: To read the Clinton-Gold Star Mothers e-mail, click here.
headline: Read the Clinton e-mail

blurb: A Special Report: Chain e-mails spread rumors about candidates at warp speed. But they often distort the truth, as we found with one that falsely claims Hillary Clinton refused to meet with the Gold Star Mothers.
headline: Mud in your inbox

blurb: Our special report on chain e-mails was suggested by several readers who had received the Clinton and Obama e-mails. If you have a suggestion for facts we should check, click here to email us.
headline: Suggestions from our readers

blurb: The Republican candidates mixed it up during a lively debate in Orlando. They stretched the truth on crime and defense, while Huckabee was Pants-On-Fire wrong about the Founding Fathers.
headline: Taking off the gloves in Orlando

blurb: To counter his history in Hollywood and Washington, he tells of growing up in rural Tennessee.
headline: Thompson's first role: factory worker

blurb: Just below the frontrunners, two Democrats tussle over Iraq.
headline: Biden: Richardson used to like my plan

blurb: Edwards bans Washington lobbyist money, but not all lobbyist money.
headline: Never say never

blurb: The candidates from both parties want to distill the SCHIP debate into nuggets that satisfy their base voters.
headline: Keeping it simple, sometimes wrong

blurb: Sen. John McCain has a history of attacking 'earmarked' spending, but his facts are in the past, too.
headline: Still fighting the last war

blurb: A campaign ad is accurate on Clinton's support for reserve troops and 9/11 workers, but inflates her stature on health care.
headline: Clinton health claims a stretch

blurb: Courting rural voters, Edwards paints a (too) bleak picture of their schools as he pushes reforms.
headline: Unfair grades for rural schools

blurb: The Republicans clashed on taxes, the economy and Iraq during a debate in Dearborn, Mich.  They fumbled a few facts along the way.
headline: McCain overbids on eBay

blurb: Philadelphia Inquirer columnist Chris Satullo gives us a nice plug in his Sunday column , saying our site is "done with both class and sass. PolitiFact renders serious reporting with a sense of humor that helps even dry issue assessments stick in the voter's mind."
headline: 'Class and sass'

blurb: Mitt Romney has consistently opposed gay marriage, but he changed positions on a constitutional amendment on civil unions.
headline: Romney's nuances on gay issues

blurb: When catering to the Democratic Party's left-wing base, it's hard to get there first.
headline: Beating Kucinich to the base

blurb: An unwavering advocate of the war, he reminds voters he has criticized the White House for its strategies.
headline: McCain's tough Iraq straddle

blurb: Romney's energy goals are ambitious but not practical.
headline: Romney energy claim unrealistic

blurb: Use a customized Google homepage? Now you can include a feed of the latest stories and statements from PolitiFact. When we publish something new, you'll be the first to know.
headline: Feed me

blurb: To stand out in the field of Iraq opponents, the Democratic candidates are angling to be first or best or most opposed.
headline: Democrats race to oppose Iraq most

blurb: An explanation of our Truth-O-Meter rulings, from True to Pants on Fire
headline: Behind the Meter

blurb: Giuliani has been an adoption advocate, but now he says that's the same as being an abortion foe.
headline: Giuliani's "culture of life," defined

blurb: From the outlandishly wrong to the solidly right.
headline: A Dartmouth numbers game

blurb: In a rich biography of success, he sometimes overstates his record.
headline: Romney: turning over the turnaround label

blurb: Keeping it simple, Obama's insurance claim is accurate.
headline: Obama won health care for many

blurb: Bill Clinton's numbers are right, but they don't quite add up
headline: Bill on Hillary: She can win anywhere

blurb: A precise figure on the cost of the Iraq war is missing in action.
headline: No easy pricetag for Iraq war

blurb: Huckabee gets the number right, but it may not mean what it says.
headline: Huckabee and the pudgy military

blurb: Clinton's health plan is not the "socialism" its critics declare, but it's skimpy on details and relies on optimistic math.
headline: Clinton's health care Rx: many options, fewer specifics

blurb: Ron Paul has the most libertarian voting record in the presidential field, but some of his claims about his record go too far.
headline: 'Dr. No' sometimes votes yes

blurb: More than a year ago, the Delaware Democrat offered a plan on Iraq. But he's no longer the only one.
headline: Biden's Iraq plan detailed enough to draw praise - and critics

blurb: Democrats and taxes make an easy target for a Republican, but Giuliani can't quite justify his claim for how high taxes would go.
headline: Giuliani says a little too much about Democrats and taxes

blurb: He's consistently voted against giving the feds authority in state matters — even when it opposes conservative ideals.
headline: Thompson on his own, 99-1

blurb: The Connecticut senator likens his low poll numbers to John Kerry's four years ago. But the numbers don't match up.
headline: Dodd wants to be Kerry

blurb: The Democrats toss around lots of numbers in the Univision debate. They're right about health insurance and the border fence, but miss the mark on NAFTA.
headline: In Miami, safety in numbers

blurb: The freshman senator calls for bipartisanship. But when he votes, it's nearly always with his party.
headline: Does Obama practice what he preaches?

blurb: In a New Hampshire debate, the GOP candidates discuss immigration, Iraq and chicken dinners for Guantanamo detainees. Some of their facts aren't quite right.
headline: Debatable claims in N.H.

blurb: McCain exaggerates when he says firing a federal worker is a "near impossibility." But experts say his broader point is true: Reforms are needed for supervisors to deal effectively with poor performers.
headline: Firing federal workers is difficult

blurb: The Democrat says he can draw black voters and young people to the polls in a big way, but experts have their doubts.
headline: Obama: I'm a magnet for turnout

blurb: The NYC crime stats look great from his tenure as mayor, but they looked great in a lot of cities.
headline: How much credit does Giuliani deserve for fighting crime?

blurb: Check out the new video of our promotional song Gimme the Truth by scrolling to the bottom of our home page. The song, written by Chris Ave and directed by Adrian Phillips, features backup vocals by Bill Clinton and Richard Nixon.
headline: PolitiFact rocks

blurb: Clinton overstates the implications of making English the official U.S. language.
headline: Clinton fails English exam - twice

blurb: The RNC goes on the offensive against the top Democrats on Iraq, but the flip-flop charge against Clinton and Obama just isn't very strong.
headline: RNC goes after Clinton, Obama on Iraq

blurb: He says more guns mean less crime. But the academic research is inconclusive.
headline: Thompson's gun claim low on ammo

blurb: Dodd says in a TV ad that he persuaded Clinton and Obama to support a March 2008 withdrawal from Iraq. But there's little evidence he was a factor in their decisions.
headline: Dodd exaggerates influence on Iraq

blurb: Mitt Romney blames the Clinton administration for shrinking the nation's military. But the shrinkage actually began under President George H.W. Bush.
headline: Romney defense claim misleading

blurb: Mitt Romney sought to deflect the criticism he has faced for his change on abortion by pointing out that Sen. John McCain has changed some positions, too.
headline: Romney says McCain flip-flops, too
